markdown.markdown:
[Welcome to the PKM Workshop]{.titletea .large}

- Learn how to organize knowledge effectively. - Explore tools: [Logseq](https://logseq.com/) and [Obsidian](https://obsidian.md/) - Build systems that work **for you**. [Today's Goal]{.titletea .large}
![](PKMslides_files/images/filter_apps.png) [My Journey]{.relative .titletea .large} ::: {.r-stack} ![](PKMslides_files/images/roadmap1.png){.absolute top=-10 right=150 width="3200" height="6500"} ![](PKMslides_files/images/roadmap2.png){.fragment .absolute top=-10 right=150 width="3200" height="6500"} ![](PKMslides_files/images/roadmap3.png){.fragment .absolute top=-10 right=150 width="3200" height="6500"} ![](PKMslides_files/images/roadmap4.png){.fragment .absolute top=-10 right=150 width="3200" height="6500"} ![](PKMslides_files/images/roadmap5.png){.fragment .absolute top=-10 right=150 width="3200" height="6500"} ::: [You are the expert]{.titletea .large .centered} ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {.fragment fragment-index="1"}
![](PKMslides_files/images/postit.jpeg){width="90%" height="90%"} ::: :::: :::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.fragment fragment-index="2"}




- No one-size-fits-all solution. - You are the expert on your own needs ::: :::: ::::::: [What is PKM]{.titletea .large}
**PKM**: **P**ersonal **K**nowledge **M**anagement
A system for **capturing**, **organizing**, and **retrieving** knowledge efficiently.
::::::: columns :::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.fragment}


**PKM helps with**:
- Information overload,
- Information retrieval,
- Scattered notes,
- Communication
::: :::: :::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {} ![](PKMslides_files/images/information_overload.png){width="60%" height="60%"} ::: :::: ::::::: [Your Current Workflow]{.titletea .large} ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.fragment}
- **Reflect on your practices**: - Tools you use (analog or digital) - How you organize notes (folders, random papers) - **Challenges**: - Losing track of papers or ideas - Overwhelming, unstructured notes
::: :::: :::: {.column width="50%"}

![](PKMslides_files/images/post-its.png){width="90%" height="90%"} :::: ::::::: [Apps to the Rescue!]{.titletea .large}


Note Taking Apps provide the practical infrastructure for implementing a PKM system

![](PKMslides_files/images/logseq-logo.png){width="24%" height="24%"} ![](PKMslides_files/images/obsidian-logo.png){width="22%" height="22%"} [Common Pitfalls]{.titletea .large} ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.slide-content} - **Challenges**: - Overcomplication - Inconsistency - Fear of starting: Blank page syndrome ::: :::: :::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.slide-content} - **Solutions**: - Start small - Build workflows iteratively - Focus on consistency ::: :::: ::::::: [Tools for PKM:]{.titletea .large}

[Logseq and Obsidian]{.midi} ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"}
**Logseq**\
- Open-source\ - Uses Markdown (future-proof)\ - Great for journaling and task management\ - Helps build structured, hierarchical notes\ :::: :::: {.column width="50%"}
**Obsidian**\
- Free with optional paid extras\ - Uses Markdown (future-proof)\ - Great for visualizing connections (Graph View)\ - Flexible with many plugins\ :::: ::::::: [Tools for PKM:]{.titletea .large}

[Why not other apps?]{.midi}

- **Privacy**: your data is stored on their servers - **Cloud-based**: require Internet for most features - **Money**: one time payment or monthly subscriptions - **These Two Work Well**: - Both Logseq and Obsidian store notes locally and work offline - They are free! [Limitations]{.titletea .large}
- **Logseq**: - Still in beta: Occasional bugs and incomplete features - Limited plugin availability compared to Obsidian - **Obsidian**: - Plugin dependency: Many advanced features rely on community plugins - Not possible to collaborate
[PKM Strategies]{.titletea .large} [Common PKM Strategies]{.titletea .large }
- Zettelkasten - Para - Second Brain - MindMapping
[Once again...]{.titletea .large}

[You are the expert]{.midi}
The **key** to Personal Knowledge Management (PKM) is organizing your knowledge in a way that ensures **you'll find it when you need it**.

**A great system isn’t about perfection**; it’s about making retrieval easy and reliable.
[Once again...]{.titletea .large}

[You are the expert]{.midi}
A good system should **support your workflow**, not distract you from it

**Do Not Perfect** your PKM structure at the expense of getting things done
[PKM Strategies]{.titletea .large} [Zettelkasten]{.titletea .large}
::::::: columns :::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.slide-content} - German for "slip-box", popularised by [Niklas Luhmann](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niklas_Luhmann) - Focuses on creating small notes cointaining one single idea - Notes are connected through meaningful links, forming a web of related ideas - **Best for**: - Developing a knowledge base that fosters creative thinking ::: :::: :::: {.column width="40%"}



![A Zettelkasten](PKMslides_files/images/zettelkasten.jpg) :::: :::::::
More info here: [Zettelkasten](https://zettelkasten.de/)
[PARA]{.titletea .large}

::::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"} - A system by [Tiago Forte](https://fortelabs.com/start-here/) for organizing all information. - **Projects**: represent active, short-term goals - **Areas**: broader, long-term responsibilities - **Resources**: library of reference materials - **Archives**: final place for anything that is no longer active :::: :::: {.column width="50%"} ![](PKMslides_files/images/PARA.png) :::: :::::::
More info here: [PARA](https://fortelabs.com/blog/para/)
[Second Brain]{.titletea .large}

::::::: columns :::: {.column width="60%"} - A framework by [Tiago Forte](https://www.buildingasecondbrain.com/) for managing and retrieving knowledge efficiently. - **Capture**: refers to efficient note-taking - **Organize**: note organization is essential to retrieve information - **Distil**: learn to summarize information - **Express**: use your notes actively - **Best for** building a personal repository of ideas and knowledge :::: :::: {.column width="40%"} ![](PKMslides_files/images/second_brain.png) :::: ::::::: [Mind Mapping]{.titletea .large}

::::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"} - A visual approach to organizing and connecting ideas. - Start with a central idea and branch out with related concepts. - **Best for**: - Brainstorming, planning, and exploring relationships visually. :::: :::: {.column width="50%"} ![](PKMslides_files/images/mind-mapping.png) :::: :::::::
More info here:[Mind Mapping](https://www.mindmapping.com/)
[What We Are Doing Now]{.titletea .large}
- **Explore Obsidian and Logseq**:
How these tools work and how they can adapt to your workflow. - **Ask Questions Freely**:
This session is all about answering your specific questions. - **What We’re NOT Covering**: *How to take notes in general*
[What is Logseq?]{.titlerose .large} [What is Logseq?]{.titlerose .large} ::::::: columns :::: {.column width="60%"}
- Open-source tool for **PKM** and **task organization** - Networked outliner - Folder agnostic
:::: :::: {.column width="40%"}

![](PKMslides_files/images/logseq-logo.png){width="50%" id="logseq-logo"} :::: ::::::: ![](PKMslides_files/images/logseq-logo.png){width="15%" .absolute top=15 left=80 id="logseq-logo"}
It helps you:
- Organize thoughts using **blocks**
- Connections ideas using **backlinks**
- Daily Journaling
![](PKMslides_files/images/logseq_structure.png){.fragment .absolute bottom=0} [Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}

[Outliner-Based Workflow]{.midi} ::: {.slide-content .miditext fragment-index="2"} - Structures notes into **blocks** (or *paragraphs*)
- *everything in Logseq is about the **blocks**!*
- Blocks can be nested hierarchically for: - Outlining ideas - Organizing complex thoughts - Easy to reorganize or move blocks ::: [Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}

[Backlinks and Linking]{.midi}
- Create links using the `[[Link Syntax]]` - Backlinks: a link for a page that is shown to the current page - Encourages a **web of interconnected notes**
[Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}

[Journaling and Daily Notes]{.midi}
- Automatically creates a **daily note** - Acts as: - A chronological log. - A launchpad for other notes.
![](PKMslides_files/images/backlinks.png){width="1900px" height="900px"} [Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}

[Task Management]{.midi}
- Integrates tasks directly into your notes: - LATER -> NOW -> DONE - TODO -> DOING -> DONE - CANCELED/CANCELLED, IN-PROGRESS, and WAIT/WAITING - Tasks can be tracked across notes using **queries**.
[Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}

[Page Properties]{.midi}
- Uses **key-value pairs** for structured data: - `priority:: A deadline:: 2024-12-01` - Helps organize and filter notes based on specific criteria
[Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}

[Queries]{.midi}
- Dynamically search for and display notes or tasks - Uses **Clojure syntax** for powerful, customizable queries - Example: {{query (and \[\[*tag-name*\]\] (priority A))}}
[Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}

[What Makes Logseq Different?]{.midi}
- **Block-Based Organization** - **Folderless Structure** - **Emphasis on Journaling** - **Open-Source and Privacy-Focused** - **Fully Functional Offline** - **Advanced Queries**
[What is Obsidian?]{.titlechampagne .large} [What Is Obsidian?]{.titlechampagne .large}
- **Local, Markdown-based knowledge management tool.** - Flexible, customizable, and **perfect for researchers.**
![](PKMslides_files/images/obsidian-logo.png){width="40%"} [Key Features of Obsidian]{.titlechampagne .large} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"}
- **Bidirectional Linking** - **Graph View** - **Markdown-Based**: Future-proof `.md` files. - **Local Storage**
::: ::: {.column width="50%"}


![](PKMslides_files/images/graph-view.png){width="120%"} ::: ::: [Using Obsidian for Research]{.titlechampagne .large}
**Literature Review**: - Create notes for papers with links to key themes. - Tag by topic (e.g., `#methods`, `#results`). - Use Graph View to see clusters of related ideas. **Thesis Writing**: - Draft sections in linked notes. - Use YAML metadata to track progress (`status: draft`).
[Obsidian vs. Logseq]{.titlechampagne .large} ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"}
**Similarities**: - Markdown-based and future-proof. - Local-first, private storage. - Powerful Graph View. - Flexible, customizable workflows.
::: ::: {.column width="50%"}
**Differences**: - *Logseq*: - Journaling and outliner focus. - Built in functions, less plugins available - *Obsidian*: - Note-based, adaptable for any system. - Extensive plugins for research and writing.
::: ::: [What We Are Doing Today]{.titlerose .large} [What We Are Doing Today]{.titlerose .large}
- **Explore the Obsidian Vault and Logseq Graph**:
How these tools work and how they can adapt to your workflow. - **Ask Questions Freely**:
This session is all about answering your specific questions. - **What We’re NOT Covering**: *How to take notes in general* - Everyone’s style is different and what works for me might not work for you.
[What To Do After Today]{.titlerose .large}
- **Reflect on Your Routine**: - When do you take notes? (e.g., recurring meetings, during experiments, etc) - Do your notes follow a common theme? - **Start Simple**: - Take one project and break it into **main topics** - Are these topics recurring across projects? (e.g., *statistics*, *foraging*)
[What To Do After Today]{.titlerose .large}
- **Build Your System Gradually**: - Test one approach at a time: Folder-based? Tag-based? Link-based? - Adjust as you learn what works best
[Designing Your Workflow]{.titlerose .large}
- **How to Start**: - Identify key goals. - Focus on 1-2 knowledge categories (e.g., literature, daily tasks). - **Build Iteratively**: - Customize templates, tags, and metadata. - Experiment!
[Final Thoughts]{.titlechampagne .large}
- **Obsidian and Logseq are what you make of them** - Start simple, grow gradually. - **Tame the chaos.** - Build your knowledge base to serve your needs.
